questions.text: Which type of pancreatic neoplasm most commonly arises in the tail of the pancreas?
questions.explanation:
Location

Tumors

Head
  • Adenocarcinoma pancreas (Option D ruled out)
  • Serous cystadenoma (Option A ruled out)
  • Intraductal Papillary Mucinous neoplasm
  • Somatostatinoma
  • PPOMA (Pancreatic Polypeptide cell tumor)

Body and tail
  • Glucagonoma
  • Mucinous cystadenoma (Option B ruled out)

Tail
  • VIPOMA (Vasoactive intestinal peptide tumor) (Option C)

Equal distribution in body, head and tail.
  • Insulinoma

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and is found to have jaundice. An ERCP is performed, revealing thick mucus extruding through the ampulla of Vater. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
What is the most common complication and common cause of death in a patient post pancreaticoduodenectomy?

options.label: C
options.text: Delayed gastric emptying, Perforated bowel obstruction

questions.correct_answer: A. Delayed gastric emptying, Pulmonary complication
questions.explanation:
Complication

Frequency (%)

Delayed gastric emptying (Option A)

18

Pancreas fistula

12

Wound infection

7

Intraabdominal abscess

6

Cardiac events

3

Bile leak

2

Overall reoperation

3

questions.text: A 48-year-old perimenopausal woman presents with abdominal discomfort. Imaging reveals a multilocular cyst with thick walls located in the pancreatic tail. Fine-needle aspiration of the cyst fluid shows high carcinoembryonic antigen levels exceeding 400 ng/mL, with normal amylase levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Adenoma of the Ampulla of Vater

questions.explanation:
Factor

MCNs

Adenomas

(Option D ruled out)

Pseudocysts (Option A ruled out)

Serous cystadenoma (Option B ruled out)

Demographics

Perimenopausal women

Varied

History of pancreatitis

Older woman

Location

Pancreatic body or tail

Ampulla of Vater

Anywhere in the pancreas

Tail of pancreas

Characteristics

Multilocular cysts, thick walls

Polypoid submucosal masses

Cysts with elevated amylase

Lobular, hypodense lesion with multiple small cysts

Key Diagnostic Tool

CEA levels (>400 ng/mL)

Endoscopy

History, imaging, amylase levels

CECT: Central stellate scar, central sunburst calcification

questions.text: A 45-year-old male has a history of recurrent peptic ulcers and severe abdominal pain. Despite the use of proton pump inhibitors, his symptoms persist. Endoscopic examination reveals small nodules in the medial wall of the duodenum. His family history is significant for multiple endocrine neoplasia type I. Which of the following statements is most likely true regarding his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The tumors are most commonly found in the tail of the pancreas.

options.label: B
options.text: The condition is curable with surgical removal of the primary tumor.

options.label: C
options.text: The patient's gastrinoma is likely located within the gastrinoma triangle.

options.label: D
options.text: The use of proton pump inhibitors has made diagnosis of this condition easier

questions.correct_answer: C. The patient's gastrinoma is likely located within the gastrinoma triangle.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Tumor Location

Duodenal loop, Pancreas (head) (Option A ruled out)

Causes

Persistent peptic ulceration

Historical Recognition

Severe peptic ulcers unresponsive to surgery pre-PPI era. The use of proton pump inhibitors has made the condition controllable but harder to recognize. (Option D ruled out)

Types

Sporadic, MEN type I (with parathyroid adenoma)

Common Locations

Gastrinoma Triangle (cystic duct/common bile duct, duodenum, pancreas) (Option C)

Detection

Small nodules in duodenal wall, endoscopic and surgical inspection needed

Course

Indolent for some malignant gastrinomas

Treatment

Palliative liver resection, liver transplantation, surgical removal for palliation in MEN type I as they are incurable. (Option B ruled out)

Prognosis

Worse for tumors outside gastrinoma triangle

questions.text: A 70-year-old female patient is evaluated for a pancreatic cystic mass. The CT scan shows a lobular, hypodense lesion with multiple small cysts, a central hyperdense scar, and scattered "sunburst" calcifications. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Shape and Density

Lobular shape; hypodense due to high water content.

Calcifications

Present in up to 30%; can show a "sunburst" pattern.

Central Fibrous Scar

Hyperdense, stellate pattern, enhances with contrast.

Enhancement Patterns

Hypervascular; fibrous portions enhance post-contrast fluid density in less fibrous areas.

Oligocystic and Macrocystic Variants

Oligocystic patterns may mimic mucinous neoplasms; macrocystic variants may resemble pseudocysts or mucinous cysts.

Differentiation

Challenging to distinguish from other cystic pancreatic neoplasms; an MRI may be needed.

questions.text: What is the most common site of gastrinoma in patients with Zollinger–Ellison syndrome
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Definition

Fulminating ulcer diathesis, recurrent ulceration, non-β islet cell tumors (gastrinoma)

Incidence
  • 0.5-4 per million, 0.1% of duodenal ulcers, 20-25% associated with MEN
  • Rarely occur in the stomach (Option A ruled out), peripancreatic lymph nodes, liver (Option D ruled out), bile duct, ovary, and heart
  • Pancreatic gastrinoma comprises 25% of the cases (Option B ruled out)

Pathology

Sporadic (duodenum, small, multiple), MEN 1 (duodenum, gastrinoma triangle)

Clinical

Peptic ulcers, diarrhea, abdominal pain, high alcohol use history

Diagnosis

Elevated FSG (fasting serum gastrin), gastric pH <2, secretin provocation test, MEN 1 screening, localization studies

Treatment

Surgery (sporadic without metastases, MEN 1 >2 cm)

Medical (PPI, SSA, locoregional therapy)

questions.text: Among the following, which option correctly describes the most common location of origin of insulinoma in the pancreas?
questions.explanation:
Location

Tumors

Head
  • Carcinoma pancreas

  • Somatostatinoma
  • PPOMA (Pancreatic Polypeptide cell tumor)

Body and tail
  • Glucagonoma
  • Mucinous cystadenoma

Tail
  • VIPOMA (Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide tumor)

Equal distribution in body, head and tail. 
  • Insulinoma

questions.explanation:

Body and tail
  • Glucagonoma
  • Mucinous cystadenoma (Option B)

Tail
  • VIPOMA ( Vasoactive intestinal peptide tumor)

Equal distribution in body, head and tail.
  • Insulinoma

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with jaundice, weight loss, and epigastric pain. Imaging reveals a mass in the head of the pancreas. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
A patient with a suspected intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN) has elevated serum CA 19-9 levels. What does this finding most likely suggest?

options.label: A
options.text: The IPMN is benign and does not require surgical intervention

options.label: B
options.text: The IPMN is likely malignant or has high-grade dysplasia

options.label: C
options.text: The IPMN is a branch duct type and requires conservative management

options.label: D
options.text: The IPMN is likely malignant and surgery is contraindicated

questions.correct_answer: B. The IPMN is likely malignant or has high-grade dysplasia
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Management Pathways

Surgical Indications: Confirmed carcinoma/high-grade dysplasia, solid mass, jaundice, mural nodules, significant duct dilation.

Non-Surgical Management: For unsuitable candidates or non-surgical criteria, with regular monitoring (clinical, CA 19-9, imaging).

Surgical Options

Pylorus-Preserving Pancreatoduodenectomy (PPPD): For pancreatic head tumors.

Distal Pancreatectomy: For body/tail tumors.

Total Pancreatectomy: For multifocal tumors, unsafe bowel anastomosis and whole duct involvement.

questions.text: In a patient with a pancreatic cyst, peripheral eggshell calcification on CT is:

options.label: A
options.text: Common in benign cysts and easily detected.

options.label: B
options.text: Easily detected and a definitive marker of malignancy.

options.label: C
options.text: Difficult to detect but highly indicative of malignancy in mucinous cystic neoplasms.

options.label: D
options.text: Exclusively associated with pancreatic pseudocysts, not with malignancy.

questions.correct_answer: C. Difficult to detect but highly indicative of malignancy in mucinous cystic neoplasms.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Calcification Type

Peripheral eggshell (Option C)

Imaging Modality

CT scan (challenging to detect) (Options A & B ruled out)

Predictive Value

High for malignancy (Option D ruled out)

Typical Patient

Middle-aged females

Cyst Characteristics

Unilocular or multilocular macrocysts

Possible Imaging Findings

Thickened wall, vascular involvement

Clinical Action

Further assessment and potential surgery

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with chronic watery diarrhea. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) > 150 pg/ml, achlorhydria, and hypokalemia. Imaging studies show a solitary mass in the body of the pancreas. What is the treatment of choice in this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Initiate high-dose corticosteroid therapy with Prednisolone

questions.text: A 58-year-old female presents with diarrhea, weight loss, and itchy lesions around the mouth and vagina. Physical examination reveals a rash as shown in the image below. On evaluation, she has diabetes, and imaging studies indicate a large pancreatic mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect Details
Origin Alpha cells of the pancreas
Common Locations Body and tail of the pancreas
Size 5-10 cm
Prevalence Sporadic; 17% with MEN type II syndrome
Gender More common in females
Malignancy 80% malignant; 80% spread to liver
Symptoms Necrolytic migratory erythema, diabetes, diarrhea, weight loss, stomatitis, anemia, amino acid deficiency, vulvovaginitis
Diagnostic Tests MRI, CT scan, Endosonography, Angiogram, Serum glucagon levels (>50 pmol/L)
Treatment Anemia and deficiency correction, IV amino acids, DVT prevention, Distal pancreatectomy, Whipple’s/total pancreatectomy, Enucleation, Dacarbazine

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a family history of cancer presents for a routine check-up. Her mother and maternal aunt both had pancreatic cancer. Genetic testing reveals a gain-of-function mutation in the PRSS1 gene. Which of the following factors contributes the most to her increased risk of developing pancreatic cancer?
questions.explanation:
Genetic Factor Relative Risk Increase
Family History (two first-degree relatives) 18-57 times
Germline BRCA2 Mutations High-risk families
Hereditary Pancreatitis 50-70 times
Chronic Pancreatitis 5-15 times

questions.text: Which diagnostic finding is most indicative of an insulinoma?

options.label: C
options.text: Elevated serum insulin levels during hypoglycemia

options.label: D
options.text: Hyperinsulinemic response to oral glucose tolerance test

questions.correct_answer: C. Elevated serum insulin levels during hypoglycemia
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Definition

A rare, typically benign tumor of the pancreatic islet cells that produces excess insulin.

Clinical Features

Whipple's Triad-

  • Documented low blood glucose levels during symptomatic episodes
  • Relief of symptoms upon administration of glucose
  • Symptoms often occur during fasting or after exercise

Symptoms of hypoglycemia (e.g., sweating, palpitations, confusion, visual disturbances, seizures)

Diagnosis
  • Gold-standard test for diagnosing insulinoma is a 72-hour fast. (Option C)
  • Combination of plasma glucose < 55 mg/dL + insulin level ≥ 3 microUnits/mL + C peptide level ≥ to 0.6 ng/mL + proinsulin ≥ 5 pmol/L, + negative sulfonylurea level indicates that the hypoglycemia induction is by hyperinsulinemia
  • Insulin/glucose ratio > 0.4 is diagnostic
  • Imaging:
    • CT, MRI, EUS

Management
  • Surgical resection is the treatment of choice
  • Medical management with diazoxide or octreotide for non-surgical candidates or unresectable tumors

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding neuroendocrine tumors of the pancreas?

options.label: A
options.text: The most common non-functional neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is insulinoma

options.label: B
options.text: Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy is used for the localization of NETs

options.label: C
options.text: The most common site of metastasis is the lungs

options.label: D
options.text: Functional NETs are diagnosed at a later stage and have poor prognosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy is used for the localization of NETs

questions.text: Which surgical procedure is characterized by the resection of the pancreatic head while preserving the stomach and pylorus?

A patient is scheduled to undergo a Whipple procedure for the treatment of pancreatic cancer. The surgeon needs to perform anastomosis to reconstruct the digestive tract after removing the affected tissues. In which sequence are the anastomoses typically performed during a Whipple procedure?
questions.explanation:
Whipple’s procedure  (Pancreaticoduodenectomy)

Structures removed: Head of the pancreas, the first part of the small intestine (duodenum), the gallbladder, and a portion of the bile duct.

Types:

  • Pylorus-Preserving Whipple Procedure (Preferred)
  • Non–Pylorus-Preserving Whipple Procedure

Indications
  • Pancreatic Cancer: Commonly treated with Whipple if cancer is localized to the head of the pancreas.
  • Chronic Pancreatitis: when uncontrolled by medical management.
  • Tumors in Pancreas/Surrounding Areas: Includes duodenum, distal bile duct, and ampulla of Vater.

Procedure Steps
  • Tumor Assessment: Explore abdomen to assess tumor size, location, and spread.
  • Resection: Remove head of pancreas, duodenum, gallbladder, and part of bile duct; this may include partial stomach resection.
  • Lymph Node Dissection: Remove and examine nearby lymph nodes.

Reconstruction
  • Pancreaticojejunostomy: Connect remaining pancreas to jejunum.
  • Hepaticojejunostomy: Connect common bile duct to jejunum.
  • Gastrojejunostomy: Connect stomach to jejunum.

Anastomosis Principles
  • Tension-Free Connection: Achieve mucosa-to-mucosa connection for healing.
  • Order of Anastomoses: Pancreaticojejunostomy → Hepaticojejunostomy → Gastrojejunostomy
  • Stent Placement: May use internal/external stents for small ducts.

Complications
  • Pancreatic Fistula: Major issue; managed with somatostatin analogues.
  • Delayed Gastric Emptying
  • Bleeding, wound infection
  • Reoperation, increased mortality
  • Dumping/Bile Reflux: Common after non-pylorus-preserving Whipple; pylorus-preserving method has uncertain benefits.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with jaundice, dark urine, and weight loss over the past two months. Courvoisier's Sign is positive on physical examination. What is the next best step in the management of this patient to both visualize pancreatic and biliary ducts, and tissue sampling?
questions.explanation:
Technique

Uses and key features

CT Scan

(Option A)
  • First choice for diagnosing pancreatic cancer.
  • Detects mass, duct dilation, and pancreatic atrophy.
  • Detection of metastasis.


 

MRI/MRCP

(Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography)
  • Complementary to CT for additional information.
  • MRCP identifies biliary obstruction and pancreatic duct issues.
  • Does not show calcification visible on CT.

ERCP

(Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography)

(Option C)
  • Visualizes pancreatic and biliary ducts.
  • Allows for tissue sampling.
  • Key signs: Narrowing of ducts, double duct sign.

EUS

(Endoscopic Ultrasound)

(Option B)
  • Useful when CT does not show a tumor.
  • Assesses vascular invasion and differentiates cystic tumors from pseudocyst

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with no history of obesity or a family history of diabetes is recently diagnosed with diabetes mellitus. He also reports vague upper abdominal discomfort, significant weight loss, and mild jaundice. Which of the following findings on physical examination would most likely suggest a diagnosis of pancreatic cancer?

A 56-year-old patient with pancreatic cancer has completed initial treatment. To monitor for potential recurrence, the oncologist decides to check a tumor marker. Which of the following tumor markers is commonly used for establishing a baseline and monitoring for recurrence in pancreatic cancer?

A 65-year-old man presents with symptoms of jaundice and abdominal pain. Imaging studies reveal a solid mass in the pancreatic head. Histological examination shows a dense fibrous stroma with neoplastic tubular glands. The tumor is characterized by local spread along nerves, lymphatics, and blood vessels, and has metastasized to the liver. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Tumor Type

Characteristics

Common Locations

Typical Patients

Ductal Adenocarcinoma

Solid tumors with neoplastic tubular glands

Pancreas (general)

-

Serous Cystadenomas (Option A ruled put)

Large clusters of small cysts

Pancreas

Older women

Mucinous Cystic Neoplasms

(Option B ruled out)

Thick-walled, multilocular cysts

Pancreatic body or tail

Perimenopausal women

Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasms (IPMNs)

Multifocal, more likely malignant

Pancreatic head

Older men

Solid Pseudopapillary Neoplasms (Option D ruled out)

Large, partially solid, partially cystic masses

Pancreas

Women of childbearing age

Adenomas of the Ampulla of Vater

Smooth, polypoid submucosal masses

Ampulla of Vater

-

Ampullary Adenocarcinomas

Early presentation with biliary obstruction

Ampulla of Vater

-
